The way powders are packed in heavy plastic bags that are supposed to be convenient but are not caused me to spill quite a bit of (fake) wasabi powder.  I swept it as best I could into the sink.  There is no real wasabi powder.  Real wasabi is made fresh in Japan.   Not in the US, as far as I know.   Ground horseradish root contains the same flavorant.  The result was, after a week of a few unwashed dishes in the sink,  ZERO cockroaches.  Dried wasabi powder must be mixed with water to activate it.   The chemical is allyl isothiocyanate, a food product and interestingly, the first food to be banned under Nixon's war on terror.  I wanted to find out if bed bugs cleaned their mouth parts.  Google don't know chemical names.  It also crabbed about the word flavorant. I am the first person to use this word at Google since 2013?  Surprising.

Diatomaceous earth will solve all your problems! Diatomaceous earth (DE) is a fossil of a single celled sea creature. The food grade DE is 100% safe and effective. This dust/powder is super fine and very SHARP to pests with exoskeleton. When the pests walk through the DE their hard outer shell (exoskeleton) is scratched. This will cause the pest to dehydrate and die. DE can be used indoors or outdoors. It can be used in gardens on plants, or even for fleas on pets. Do your research when using it on pets, too much too often can dry their skin out. Better to treat the house, bedding, etc. when dealing with fleas. You can deworm pets with DE. Just an option, I have used it for years! Now I am not a vet, doctor, or exterminator....and I do NOT play one on TV...just some tips that worked for me.

As a person who worked for a slum lord rehabbing apartments, I'd never go into an apartment without wearing atleast two pairs of cover-all suits. Even if it was 90 degrees. When I'd get home, I would still take my clothes off and dry thrm on max heat for the max amount of time i could set on my dryer. Seriously, these things can infest and ruin a household in a matter of weeks. You pretty much have to throw all your furniture away, as most bed bug repellents arent effective at all. These things are so resilient. We would heat treat apartments infested with them. The temp would reach up to 180 degrees F. It would get so hot that the blinds and window frames would literally start to melt. Yet, the next day we would still get complaints of bed bugs still roaming around. Do NOT mess around if you ever find yourself in a situation where bed bugs are present.

I remember back around 04-05 we had a big epidemic in NYC and it was bad. Hardware stores couldn't keep up with demand. The lines were long and the mases were embarrassed but the guy at the counter was great, he said, listen guys, plz don't be scared or embarrassed, you are not alone. We been having lines like this for the last two weeks. He explained the banning of DDT I belive it was or DDX and that the bugs have made a huge come back especially in the tourist industry and I just happened to go cruise that year and yes I did find them there. But this guy I gotta say made a killing at the counter, remember theirs a line almost out the door. He first made us buy spray for the eggs, another to kill the bugs and one last one which I had no idea what it was for. The order in sequence to use the spray also was confusing but at the end the bill was huge, just under $200.00. Then you figure 200 to beat these things but at least we will win...ooops! No! Just as we are ready to go he now tells us that doing this process once won't get rid of the problem which means more money, he says we need to do it at least two more times till all the bugs are dead and eggs are done. Oh and just one last thing, his last injury to insult...you guys, meaning us people that was there for the bedbugs, you guys are gonna have to take everything that's infected and sarran wrap it then throw it out. All your cloths must be put in garbage bags and thrown out...i remember looking around the crowd to see thier reactions to check if they were feeling what I was feeling and every mouth was open wide, every expression was the same, stunned in stone. I never knew or really heard of bedbugs before this crisis only in a nursery rym but who knew the emotional destruction, kaos, financial destruction, and sheer panic this little bug no bigger then a match head would cause. A few months latter it got so bad in the city that I remember reading in one paper how one guys house was so bad he had to sleep on his masseuse table and greese the table legs so they wouldn't get to him. One night he says, he's watching one climing the wall, makes it to the ceiling, walks across the middle, stops right at were he is on the table reading, then calmly adjusted itself to where the man center of mass was and incredibly to his surprise jumped down onto him. I'll tell you if true, then that's where we drew the line. I know at the present we thankfully in the East Coast have it under control. Now if one apartment gets it here in NYC three units manditorly have to be exterminated which is good. I hope things never , ever go back to those awful days.

93% isopropyl alcohol.
It sucks the moisture out of them and desiccates them.

93% alcohol is cheap and if you saturate folds and crevices where you see them or suspect them, you'll mummify every one of the little annoyances.

I read about how they can survive long periods without blood and how the can smell you at night so I made sure I left the tape long enough before removing. Twice I have lived in buildings with bed bugs, and while so many others were continuing to be infested, I was able to rid my living space of the critters all together. I used three tactics that have worked every time. 1. Wrapping mattress and boxspring in the thick Moving Plastic that comes on on brand new mattresses and taping up any breathing holes in the plastic with duct tape. The Bug resistant pillow covers work well, but the ones they make for mattresses have too much stitching and folds that bedbugs still can nest in. So just straight plastic. 2. Using a microfiber blanket with no seams or stitched ribbing. 3. Spray everything down with straight rubbing alcohol until damp. It not only will dissolve the critters and their eggs, but it also drys them out internally. If the alcohol doesn't work immediately spray a little more. 1-2 saturating sprays will kill them dead. NOTE: a fourth trick that can be used is to fill four tuna cans just little bit with rubbing alcohol and place those under your bed post leg. This prevents the bugs from even being able to get to your bed. But do this along with the plastic, microfiber blanket. There are sites and articles that claim that the alcohol doesn't work, But I'm telling you, it does, and you'll always notice that those sites are trying to sell you some other product or service.

Pull everything off the wall, take your mattress off the bed and wash all your sheets and comforters. Wipe EVERYTHING down with the alcohol. Spray your mattress with the alcohol. Vaccum your carpet then sprinkle the DE across it and along the edges. I just let it sit there for a couple of hours and then vacuumed it up but left it along the edges. slept like a baby that night.

I’ve probably had about three or four bed bug infestations and it is not fun. I’d wake up multiple times throughout the night because the itch was so bad. I once woke up to use the bathroom, only to find three bed bugs on my stomach. I ended up throwing away my mattress and bed frame. When my family and I moved to a different house, they came with us. I would find a bed bug in my notebook at school, inside my backpack, and on my clothes. I would wake up in the middle of the night to sleep on the floor because my feet and arms were itching so badly, and I’d use a towel for a blanket while my actual blanket was being cleaned. When the time came to clean my mattress, I’d find eggs and adults in every corner.

Finally, after a long time, I think it’s safe to assume I don’t have bed bugs in my house anymore. Needless to say, I’ve developed a deep hatred for these creatures.

I worked in pest control for years. Bed bugs did not become resistant to DDT, that’s just not true. Nothing becomes resistant to DDT, not even humans which is part of the reason it was banned from the US market decades ago. Bed bugs were completely gone from the US for more than 40 yrs but foreign travelers have reintroduced them to the US and we really don’t have anything that’s highly effective at killing them now that DDT is gone.

Had to take a shower after watching this. 2.5 years ago we lost all our furniture and clothes because some one in our apartment building brought home a little visitor and passed it around via the washers in the building. By the time we figured it out it was too late, the building was infested. We had to scrap all of the furniture that had fabric and any clothes in our unit. The entire building (16 units) had to be fumigated twice. The management let our rent slide for two months and located us into a different unit. I'm disabled and can't get around much. I was covered in bites and had several open sores from this. My doctor was visibly repulsed and angry. He recommended that I go to the hospital for possible blood poisoning. I couldn't due to obvious financial burdens. This was a nightmare given form; my wife now sprays everything with alcohol, and we have all the pillows and mattresses in zippered covers that are bed bug prove. We put down Diatomaceous Earth around the apartment and all around the building's communal washing machine and dryer.

“No more parasites, you say?”

Me: “No, more parasites I say. Parasites are awesome to learn about”

ATTENTION ALL:


Get food grade diatomaceous soil. It won't hurt yourself or pets. Also, spraying them with rubbing alcohol kills them immediately. So spray that stuff everywhere you suspect bed bugs are and be VERY proactive and generous with the diatomaceous earth. Eventually you will win the battle. Just don't let your guard down and stay on top of it even if you think they are gone. Keep hammering them for weeks/months. Be relentless because they are relentless with you.

For those that don't know what diatomaceous soil is, it's basically like spreading tiny razor blades on the ground(Not a chemical). It's ground up fossilized microscopic diatoms(You can even eat the food grade stuff if you suspect you have some type parasite in your body. Completely safe to consume.). The bed bugs walk across it and cut themselves all over, bring it back to the next, pass it on to their relatives and ultimately they dehydrate because of the holes made in their exoskeletons.

The reason humans loathe them so much is because they don't just walk around aimlessly, they walk with purpose, feed on you when you sleep and will flee if they see us or if lights go on. Worthless POS parasites.

MUCH EASIER THAN FINDING A BUNCH OF BEAN LEAVES: FIND SOME DUCK TAPE AND/OR VASELINE. Just wrap the tape sticky side facing out around the bottom of any surface you sleep or sit on (bed posts and such). You can also use vaseline around bedposts and rails. They cant climb thru vaseline and they get stuck on duct tape. If they cant get to you to feed off you they starve and die. I would also recommend diachotomus earth food grade, found at Walmart or any feed store for livestock and sprinkle around baseboards of every room and leave it for a month or so. It will cut them to pieces when they walk thru it and they will bleed out and die. Both of these methods work, they work even faster if you put them together and for about 20 bucks you can rid yourself of the problem pretty quickly.

Well, there is an extremely harmless powder pesticide called Dimilin. It kills by preventing insects that molt and use Chitin for their shell from reforming a new shell after they molt. It kills fleas, Bedbugs,Dragonflies, grasshoppers ....That kind of stuff and a few more waterborn organisms that use Chitin. It only takes one Gram per thousand gallons of water. It's proven harmless to livestock and humans in much much  larger doses. It doesn't even pass through to milk in milk cows.   It's perfectly legal, but finding it in the United States is hard. You gotta go to Ebay and buy it from places like Thailand for the aquarium and pond market.

bedbugs arent fun to deal with, but they're not impossible to get rid of, during one of my past leases I picked up a bed bug problem from my apartment, took a bit of work and some OCD checking for new bed bugs, but with a combination of regular sheet and bed spread changes, washes, and hot dries, and a spray mix of half and half water and isopropol alcohol in their preferred spots to nest, I managed to kill them off, and keep them from coming back. I've since gotten rid of the bed they were living in, as its box spring was badly damaged, and it wasn't quite big enough for me, but the only bedbugs I found when I got rid of it were all long dead.

Long story short, if you have bedbugs, change your sheets weekly, always put them straight through the wash, and dry them on high heat, and check for bedbugs in fabric folds, seams, and corners of your mattress, if you spot them gathering in a spot, spray it down with a 50/50 mix of water and isopropol alcohol, and make sure the room is well ventilated. If you can't do that, crank the heat in the room up to 55 degrees celsius or higher, and keep it there for an hour or two, that'll kill any bedbugs in the room.

Different insects have different structures on their feet, and what works on one kind of insect may not affect another. Bedbugs are as closely related to aphids as ants are to wasps, so they have the same feet structure as aphids. Those kinds of leaves don't prevent pollinating insects because their feet are a different structure. True bugs have a soft, vulnerable area between the two claws on their feet, but on some insects, like pollinating bees, that area is one solid piece of chitin, so it doesn't affect them. Fun facts
